Summary My current position entails regular spatial data creation, maintenance and analysis. Manipulating vector data, interpreting aerial imagery, digitization and updating attribute information. I also am responsible for troubleshooting internal tools and correcting sensitive data. 
 
I have a background in applying applying Geographic Information Systems to problems that range from analyzing policy's spatial impact on physical systems with satellite based imagery to historic mapping and promoting digital humanities. 
 
My past work and education experiences include working in enterprise GIS environments, learn new software and analysis tools, present research at professional meetings, and collaborate on multi-institutional projects.  
 
Specialties: Geographic Information Systems, Remote Sensing, Web Mapping, Management, Collaboration, Outreach, STEM Education. Summary Currently serving to detect and troubleshoot data problems for Google Maps, as well as carry out metrics reporting, training, documentation, and team management tasks. I've taken this opportunity to hone my proficiency with digital cartographic systems, spreadsheets, presentations, and documents in the field of computer technology. I take self-education very seriously and endeavor to increase my understanding of internal systems, data management, and coding every day. 
 
 
I am a Geology graduate of Western Washington University (WWU), where my undergraduate research involved XRD, SEM-EDAX, and thin-section analysis of clay minerals and alteration mineralization in rock cores from the Kilgore mine of Idaho. I presented my thesis to a panel of my peers and instructors in March, 2012.  
 
Just before starting this research, I completed field mapping as a part of WWU's geology field camp in Oregon, Idaho, and Montana during the summer of 2011. This involved six weeks of highly-involved projects to teach and improve field methodology and geologic understanding. 
 
Prior to engagement with Geology, I worked with register systems, customer service, and horticulture. This included providing information and troubleshooting for various garden issues. 
 
I pride myself in my technical skills as well, having learned several types of welding and steel work, minor computer troubleshooting, minor woodworking, ARC GIS mapping, landscaping and maintenance, and several specialized skills regarding computer software.

Summary Whether it's making latte art teddy bears as a barista at Microsoft, or becoming proficient with the GIS software and internal debugging tools as a data specialist at Google Maps, I shamelessly nerd out on things that require focus and analytical nitpicking. The pillars of my working style are technical mastery, adaptive creativity, and making things elegant. As a lead at Google Maps, I help manage a team of 20 data specialists by providing training and guidance with tool usage and debugging, as well as knowing and interpreting policy. I keep close contact with management, HR, and other leads to ensure that communication of goals and expectations flows smoothly. I also keep track of the documentation, personnel, and progress of a constantly changing queue of projects ranging from sweet and simple to bizarre and dynamic.  
 
The management and mentors I've had the pleasure of encountering at Google Maps have made it easy for me to do my best at work and to enjoy my job. Everyone deserves that opportunity, and I prioritize reaching out to my coworkers to make sure they're confident with the processes and tools, and that they feel safe and valued in their workplace.  
 
My interests include but are not limited to project documentation, workflow development, skincare, nanomaterials, ceramic engineering, hiking and backpacking, medium format film photography, and a budding obsession with fantasy football. If you would like to connect with me regarding any, all, or none of those things, please reach out! I am not currently looking for a job, but I would love to make new professional acquaintances and renew/maintain contact with people already in my network. Summary I have a passion for helping the environment and an interest in making the world a better place. I have worked in many settings: factories, sales (in person, phone and retail), all sorts of jobs in restaurants (sever, bartender, host, cook, bus boy, dishwasher, etcetera), lab assistant, janitor, and until 2011 worked for United States Postal Service as both a mail carrier and a clerk, then I went on to spend two years working for Google maps. My varied job experience gives me insight into the way many different types of businesses work and allows me to apply innovative ideas to diverse situations. 
 
In December of 2010, I graduated from the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh with a Bachelor of Science degree in Geography with a global insights emphasis. My courses included various disciplines, such as urban planning and sustainability, besides the cartography, biodiversity and math and science classes you would expect. Some of my strengths include: math skills, interpreting and analyzing information and researching to develop advanced ideas for presentation. This can be seen in my class work, such as papers (for example I’ve done both research papers and executive summaries) and projects, which are available upon your request. Additionally, in college today, group work is emphasized. Often times, being the oldest in the group and often in the class, I had to take the reins and lead the group. In many cases, I would make certain our group completed the task well and on time.  
 
My geography degree has taught me to consider all sorts of data and information and compare, combine and reconfigure it into actionable, useable presentations or reports. Of course, my degree work also included the spatial and map skills most people think of when they hear geography. Furthermore, my coursework involved making presentations, including maps, power point presentations, research papers, charts, graphs, and poster presentations.
